posts.name: Griffin Drinkwater
posts.cooked: Hi there! We are currently working on fixing a problem with the phoenix tuner. Essentially, using velocity closed-loop, our motor always goes to the max velocity unless it is set to 0 when it stops (if it‚Äôs set to negative it just goes to max velocity in the negative direction). We can‚Äôt understand why, this happens when setting velocity using the tuner and when setting velocity in code. Percent output works fine though. Any help is appreciated! -Team 5000

posts.name: Griffin Drinkwater
Dan Katzuv
posts.cooked: Could you please upload the code to GitHub/Pastebin, or at least edit your post and wrap the code with three ticks (`) on each side? I‚Äôm on my phone and it‚Äôs pretty difficult to read the code that way.

posts.name: Griffin Drinkwater
posts.cooked:
Contribute to hammerheads5000/2022RapidReact development by creating an account on GitHub.

It‚Äôs under the morePIDWorkOnFlywheels branch. LMK if you can‚Äôt access it and I can shoot my mentors an email.

posts.name: Dan Katzuv
Jack
posts.cooked:
Some possible sources of error:

Confirm your units for your feed forward terms is consistent with how you characterized. Your description closely matches the outcome of this error.

Manually calculate what your PID is doing with the value ranges to make sure they make sense. Characterization should have given you the proper feedback values.

posts.name: Agrim Sharma
posts.cooked: It appears that you are multiplying the rpm (5600) by 2048/600 which essentially maxes out the velocity. Max velocity on falcon is 6380 rpm.

posts.name: Griffin Drinkwater
posts.cooked: 1 seems to be the likely culprit looking back on my characterization. I had it in rotations. How would I get it to units / 100ms? It gives me the options: Meters, Feet, Inches, Radians, Rotations, Degrees. Thank you!

posts.name: Griffin Drinkwater
posts.cooked: Yes, we have been setting the rpm manually to test our shooter‚Äôs capabilities. The problem is that when I set the motor to 5600 rpm the motor goes to 6380 rpm. Thank you for responding.

posts.name: Griffin Drinkwater
posts.cooked: Does the velocity method take rpm? I thought it took units / 100ms. Thank you for the response.

posts.name: Griffin Della Grotte
posts.cooked: Here is the relevant page in the CTRE docs that should answer all your questions: Motor Controller Closed Loop ‚Äî Phoenix documentation

posts.name: Cory

link_counts.title: Motor Controller Closed Loop ‚Äî Phoenix documentation

posts.name: Griffin Drinkwater
posts.cooked: This worked like a charm! Did you use SysID to find your kF value? If so what units did you use, we used rotations and clearly it didn‚Äôt work very well.

posts.name: Cory
posts.cooked:
Most of these examples were manually tuned with regards to PID, and calculated for F. I‚Äôve never used SysID, so I can‚Äôt comment on how to use it with our products.

F in this case was calculated exactly following the guide here Motor Controller Closed Loop ‚Äî Phoenix documentation - We ran the falcon at maximum output, took a self-test snapshot to measure ~20660 units/100ms, and calculated an F gain of 1023 / 20660 = ~0.05. I‚Äôd suggest you do a similar test for your mechanism, as the F gain is typically mechanism-dependent.

link_counts.title: Motor Controller Closed Loop ‚Äî Phoenix documentation

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
The CTRE F gain is in units of 1 / (sensor ticks / 100ms) .  The corresponding SysId constant is kV , which in your case has units of volts / (rotations / second) .

You can convert between the two, but you need to do some dimensional analysis that depends on your mechanism.
